On March 5, 2025, the Texas A&M Queer Empowerment Council, a recognized student organization, filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Texas against the Texas A&M Board of Regents and university officials. The student organization was represented by the Foundation for Individual Rights and Expression (FIRE). The case was assigned to Senior U.S. District Judge Lee H. Rosenthal.

The lawsuit challenged the Board of Regents' February 28, 2025 resolution banning drag shows from campus "Special Event Venues." The student organization had been hosting an annual drag show called "Draggieland" at the campus Rudder Theatre since 2020, with the 2025 performance scheduled for March 27. The show was fully funded by the student group, not the university, and featured performers in a pageant-style format discussing what drag means to them. Past performances had sold out the 750-seat theater.

The Board's resolution stated that drag shows were inconsistent with the university's values because they "demean women" and involve "mockery or objectification of women," potentially creating a hostile environment under Title IX. The Board also cited President Trump's January 20, 2025 executive order on "Defending Women From Gender Ideology Extremism" as justification, arguing that allowing drag shows might violate federal funding restrictions.

The student organization brought claims under 42 U.S.C. §§ 1983 and 1988 and the Declaratory Judgment Act, alleging violations of the First and Fourteenth Amendments. They argued the ban constituted impermissible viewpoint discrimination and a prior restraint on speech. The complaint also included a claim under the Texas Open Meetings Act, alleging the Board provided inadequate public notice for its February 28 meeting.

The student organization immediately sought a temporary restraining order and preliminary injunction to allow the March 27 performance to proceed. After expedited briefing and a hearing on March 18, 2025, Judge Rosenthal granted the preliminary injunction on March 24, 2025. The court found that drag shows are protected expressive conduct under the First Amendment and that the Board's ban constituted impermissible viewpoint discrimination. The court determined the Rudder Theatre was a designated public forum and that the ban was not narrowly tailored to serve compelling governmental interests. The preliminary injunction allowed Draggieland to proceed as scheduled on March 27, 2025, without requiring the student organization to post a bond.

The defendants filed a notice of appeal to the Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals on March 28, 2025 (case no. 25-20108), along with a motion to stay the preliminary injunction pending appeal. The case remains active with ongoing proceedings regarding the stay motion and the underlying constitutional claims.

This case was filed on March 31, 2025, by Inclusiv, Inc., a nonprofit Community Development Financial Institution, against the Environmental Protection Agency, EPA Administrator Lee Zeldin, Acting Deputy Administrator W.C. McIntosh, and Citibank, N.A. The case challenges EPA's termination of grants under the Greenhouse Gas Reduction Fund (GGRF) program. Judge Tanya S. Chutkan is presiding.

In 2022, Congress created the GGRF through the Inflation Reduction Act, appropriating nearly $27 billion for clean energy and pollution reduction through three competitive grant programs. Inclusiv, which has a 50-year history of supporting credit unions and disadvantaged communities, applied for and received a $1.87 billion grant in April 2024 under the Clean Communities Investment Accelerator program. The grant was designed to provide funding and technical assistance to community lenders who would finance clean technology deployment in low-income communities.

Under the program structure, grant funds were held by Citibank as a financial agent rather than the U.S. Treasury. In September 2024, Citibank and Treasury entered into a Financial Agency Agreement, and in November 2024, Inclusiv, EPA, and Citibank executed an Account Control Agreement governing fund disbursement. The Account Control Agreement placed Citibank in a ministerial role, obligating it to comply with Inclusiv's instructions for fund disposition.

Inclusiv selected 108 credit unions across 27 states and Puerto Rico as subrecipients for $651 million in committed funds, providing written notice to EPA on February 12 and 14, 2025. However, on February 12, 2025, EPA Administrator Zeldin publicly announced intentions to "claw back" all GGRF grants and "return the entire fund balance to the U.S. Treasury." Since mid-February 2025, GGRF funds have been frozen, preventing Inclusiv and other grantees from accessing their awarded funds.

On March 11, 2025, EPA sent substantively identical termination letters to all GGRF grant recipients, signed by Acting Deputy Administrator McIntosh. The letters cited "substantial concerns regarding program integrity, the award process, programmatic fraud, waste, and abuse, and misalignment with the Agency's priorities." EPA relied on 2 C.F.R. §§ 200.339-340 and claimed "inherent authority to reconsider prior determinations." The letters provided no specific evidence of wrongdoing and gave recipients no opportunity to challenge the termination.

Inclusiv's complaint asserts ten counts against EPA defendants and three counts against Citibank. Against EPA, the nonprofit alleges violations of the Administrative Procedure Act, claiming EPA's actions were arbitrary and capricious, not in accordance with law, and exceeded statutory authority by violating the Inflation Reduction Act, Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act, Anti-Deficiency Act, and EPA's own regulations. The complaint also raises constitutional challenges under the Separation of Powers doctrine (Legislative Vesting Clause, Spending and Appropriations Clauses, and Take Care Clause) and the Due Process Clause of the Fifth Amendment. Against Citibank, Inclusiv alleges breach of contract, conversion, and replevin for the bank's refusal to disburse funds according to Inclusiv's lawful instructions.

Inclusiv sought declaratory and injunctive relief, including a declaration that EPA's termination letter is void, permanent injunctions against EPA's unlawful actions, and orders requiring Citibank to comply with its contractual obligations. The nonprofit filed a motion for preliminary injunction and briefly sought emergency relief through a temporary restraining order, which was later withdrawn.

On April 15, 2025, the court consolidated this case with the lead case No. 25-cv-698, which involves similar challenges to EPA's GGRF terminations by other grant recipients. The court denied Inclusiv's preliminary injunction motion as moot on April 16, 2025, directing that all future filings be made in the lead case. Private counsel from Venable LLP represents Inclusiv, with several attorneys admitted pro hac vice during the proceedings.

On April 11, 2025, five international students proceeding under pseudonyms filed suit in the Northern District of California challenging the unlawful termination of their Student and Exchange Visitor Information Systems (SEVIS) records by U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement. The students sued Secretary of Homeland Security Kristi Noem, Acting ICE Director Todd M. Lyons, Acting Field Office Director Moises Becerra, and President Donald J. Trump, all in their official capacities. The students were represented by private counsel from Van Der Hout LLP.

Between April 4-8, 2025, ICE's Student and Exchange Visitor Program terminated the SEVIS records of hundreds of F-1 visa holders nationwide, including all five plaintiffs. The terminations cited "Otherwise Failing to Maintain Status – Individual identified in criminal records check and/or has had their visa revoked" as the reason. The students alleged that their minor criminal histories—which included a misdemeanor DUI conviction, a dismissed disturbing the peace charge, dismissed criminal charges, and arrests without charges—did not meet the regulatory standards for status termination under 8 C.F.R. § 214.1. Some students also had their visas revoked by the State Department.

The students brought claims under the Administrative Procedure Act, alleging the SEVIS terminations were unauthorized, arbitrary and capricious, and violated procedural due process. They also asserted Fifth Amendment due process violations. They sought declaratory relief finding the terminations unlawful, restoration of their SEVIS records, and injunctive relief preventing enforcement actions, detention, and removal.

The case was initially assigned to Judge Noel Wise, who granted the students' motion to proceed under pseudonyms on April 17, 2025. On April 16, 2025, the students filed a motion for a temporary restraining order. Judge Wise granted the TRO on April 17, 2025, enjoining defendants from arresting, detaining, or transferring the students and from imposing legal effects based on the SEVIS terminations. The case was then reassigned to Judge Jeffrey S. White due to relatedness with similar cases.

Judge White extended the TRO on April 25, 2025, and conducted hearings on the preliminary injunction motion. On May 22, 2025, Judge White granted the motion for preliminary injunction. The government filed a notice of appeal to the Ninth Circuit on July 21, 2025 (Case No. 25-4523), and subsequently moved to stay the injunction pending appeal in August 2025. The case was related to multiple similar cases involving international students facing SEVIS terminations under comparable circumstances.

The Corporation for Public Broadcasting, its Board of Directors, and individual board members Laura G. Ross, Thomas E. Rothman, and Diane Kaplan filed this case on April 29, 2025, against President Donald J. Trump and other federal defendants including the White House Presidential Personnel Office and the Office of Management and Budget. The case is being litigated by private counsel from Saul Ewing LLP before Judge Randolph D. Moss in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia.

The dispute arose on April 28, 2025, when Trent Morse, Deputy Director of Presidential Personnel, sent emails to three of the five sitting CPB board members purporting to terminate their positions on behalf of President Trump. The terse email stated only: "On behalf of President Donald J. Trump, I am writing to inform you that your position on the Corporation for Public Broadcasting is terminated effective immediately. Thank you for your service." If effective, this action would have left CPB with only two active board members out of its authorized nine-member board.

The plaintiffs argue that the President lacks authority to remove CPB board members because Congress deliberately structured CPB as an independent private nonprofit corporation insulated from government interference. The Public Broadcasting Act of 1967 explicitly states that CPB "will not be an agency or establishment of the United States Government" and that board members are "not officers or employees of the United States." The Act also forbids "any department, agency, officer, or employee of the United States to exercise any direction, supervision, or control over" CPB. Plaintiffs contend this statutory scheme provides only one mechanism for removal: automatic forfeiture when a board member fails to attend at least 50 percent of board meetings in a calendar year.

The defendants' position, as reflected in the court's analysis, is that while the Act grants the President appointment authority with Senate consent, it does not expressly address removal authority. Under D.C. nonprofit corporation law, which governs CPB, directors appointed by persons other than members may be removed by those same persons unless the articles of incorporation or bylaws provide otherwise. At the time of the purported removals, CPB's governing documents contained no removal restrictions, though the board subsequently amended its bylaws on May 15, 2025, to prohibit removal without a two-thirds vote of other directors.

The plaintiffs filed claims under the Administrative Procedure Act alleging the removals were not in accordance with law and exceeded statutory authority, as well as constitutional claims for violations of separation of powers, ultra vires presidential action, and violations of the Presentment, Appropriations, and Take Care Clauses. They sought both declaratory judgment that the removal email has no legal effect and injunctive relief preventing defendants from interfering with CPB's governance.

The plaintiffs immediately moved for a temporary restraining order, which the parties later agreed to treat as a motion for preliminary injunction after a hearing on May 14, 2025. On June 8, 2025, Judge Moss denied the preliminary injunction motion. The court concluded that plaintiffs had not demonstrated a likelihood of success on the merits or irreparable harm. While acknowledging the "important questions regarding the status of the Corporation and its relationship with the federal government," the judge found that D.C. corporate law permitted the President's removal action at the time it occurred, before CPB amended its bylaws. The court also noted that CPB could continue operating with fewer directors through a "designated body" provision in its bylaws that allows former directors to serve temporarily.

The case references similar recent actions by the administration, including the forcible takeover of the U.S. Institute of Peace headquarters by federal agents and Department of Government Efficiency staff in March 2025. A DOGE staff member also contacted remaining CPB board members in April 2025 about "getting a DOGE team assigned to the organization," though no further government interference materialized.

Following the preliminary injunction ruling, the parties established an expedited summary judgment briefing schedule. However, two of the individual plaintiffs—Laura Ross and Thomas Rothman—voluntarily dismissed their claims in July and August 2025, leaving CPB, its Board of Directors, and Diane Kaplan as the remaining plaintiffs. Summary judgment motions were filed in July 2025, with briefing scheduled to conclude in October 2025.

This case was filed on April 7, 2025, in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of West Virginia before Judge Irene C. Berger. Harry Wiley, a coal miner, brought this class action lawsuit on behalf of himself and all coal miners with evidence of pneumoconiosis (black lung disease) against Robert F. Kennedy Jr., in his official capacity as Secretary of Health and Human Services, and the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services. The plaintiff is represented by private counsel, Mountain State Justice (a legal services organization), and Appalachian Mountain Advocates.

The case arises from defendants' decision to effectively shut down the Coal Workers' Health Surveillance Program (CWHSP) and related "Part 90" job transfer program operated by the Respiratory Health Division within the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health (NIOSH) in Morgantown, West Virginia. These programs, mandated by the Coal Mine Health and Safety Act and Mine Safety and Health Act (30 U.S.C. § 843), provide medical screening for coal miners and the right to transfer to low-dust jobs when they develop black lung disease. On April 1, 2025, defendants terminated or placed on administrative leave nearly all employees in the Respiratory Health Division, including the chief medical officer, effectively shuttering these critical health and safety programs.

The plaintiff Harry Wiley is a coal miner with 38 years of experience who was diagnosed with black lung disease in November 2024. He submitted an application for Part 90 job transfer rights to NIOSH in November 2024 but received no response due to the program closure. Black lung is a progressive, incurable disease that worsens with continued dust exposure, making early intervention and job transfers critical to prevent debilitating progression.

Wiley's claims are brought under the Administrative Procedure Act (5 U.S.C. §§ 702, 706), alleging that defendants' actions were arbitrary, capricious, and contrary to law. He also alleges violations of the Fifth Amendment's Due Process Clause. The plaintiff seeks declaratory judgment that defendants must comply with their statutory duties and injunctive relief requiring restoration of the terminated programs.

On April 21, 2025, plaintiff filed a motion for preliminary injunction. After a hearing on May 7, 2025, that included testimony from NIOSH employees and affected miners, Judge Berger granted the preliminary injunction on May 13, 2025. The court found that plaintiff demonstrated a likelihood of success on the merits, irreparable harm from continued dust exposure without access to job transfer rights, and that the public interest favored maintaining the congressionally mandated programs. The court ordered that the reduction-in-force notices be enjoined and rescinded to facilitate full restoration of the NIOSH Respiratory Health Division, and that there be no gap in the protections and services mandated by Congress. Defendants were required to submit written certification of compliance within 20 days.

The court rejected defendants' arguments that the case involved non-reviewable personnel decisions, finding instead that plaintiff challenged the elimination of statutorily required programs, not employment actions per se. The court also found that the program closure constituted final agency action subject to review under the APA, despite defendants' arguments that their reorganization was still in progress.

On July 9, 2025, plaintiff moved for leave to file a second amended complaint, which was granted on August 14, 2025. The case remains active with trial scheduled for May 4, 2026. The preliminary injunction requires defendants to maintain the coal miner health surveillance and job transfer programs during the pendency of the litigation.

This case was filed on May 17, 2025, by Darwin Antonio Arevalo Millan, a Venezuelan citizen and asylum applicant, against President Donald J. Trump and various federal officials and agencies. The case arose from President Trump's March 2025 issuance of Proclamation No. 10903, which invoked the Alien Enemies Act to authorize the immediate apprehension and removal of Venezuelan citizens who are members of the Tren de Aragua gang.

Arevalo, who had been granted work authorization and parole to remain in the United States while his asylum application was pending, was arrested during a scheduled ICE check-in without prior notice or documentation of the arrest basis. He was informed that his detention was based on his Venezuelan nationality and basketball-related tattoos that could potentially indicate gang affiliation. Arevalo filed both a habeas corpus petition and a class action complaint asserting 20 claims under the U.S. Constitution, California Constitution, and various statutes.

The case seeks declaratory and injunctive relief to prevent the government from removing class members under the Alien Enemies Act without adequate notice and process. The proposed class includes all noncitizens in custody in the Central District of California who are subject to the March 2025 Proclamation. Judge John W. Holcomb is presiding over the case.

On May 19, 2025, the court granted a temporary restraining order, and on June 2, 2025, certified the class and issued a preliminary injunction. The preliminary injunction enjoins the government from removing Arevalo or class members under the Alien Enemies Act or Proclamation pending further court order regarding adequate notice requirements, and from transferring them out of the judicial district except for lawful removal orders under the Immigration and Nationality Act. The court required Arevalo to post a nominal $1 bond.

The government challenged Arevalo's standing, arguing he was detained under the Immigration and Nationality Act rather than the Alien Enemies Act. However, the court found Arevalo faced an imminent threat of removal under the Proclamation based on the government's inability to provide assurances otherwise. While the court concluded that Arevalo was unlikely to succeed on his challenge to the Proclamation's validity, it found he was likely to succeed on his due process claims regarding inadequate notice and process before removal.

Arevalo was granted asylum on June 9, 2025, but remained in ICE custody. On June 14, 2025, he filed an emergency ex parte application for a writ of habeas corpus seeking immediate release. The court denied this application on June 20, 2025, finding that the government could lawfully detain him under 8 U.S.C. § 1225(b)(2)(A) pending the government's appeal of his asylum grant. The government filed a notice of appeal of the preliminary injunction order on August 1, 2025, which was assigned Ninth Circuit case number 25-4866.

The case is part of broader nationwide litigation challenging the Trump administration's use of the Alien Enemies Act against Venezuelan nationals, with the Supreme Court having previously ruled in related cases that detainees subject to removal under the Act are entitled to notice and an opportunity to challenge their removal in their district of confinement.

On May 22, 2025, Shira Perlmutter, the Register of Copyrights and Director of the U.S. Copyright Office, filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against President Donald J. Trump and other federal officials, represented by Democracy Forward Foundation and Munger, Tolles & Olson LLP. The case was assigned to Judge Timothy J. Kelly.

The dispute began when President Trump fired Librarian of Congress Carla D. Hayden on May 8, 2025, reportedly over concerns about diversity, equity, and inclusion initiatives. Two days later, acting through White House Presidential Personnel Office officials Sergio Gor and Trent Morse, the President purportedly terminated Perlmutter from her position as Register of Copyrights, effective immediately. The President then appointed Deputy Attorney General Todd Blanche as acting Librarian of Congress, who subsequently designated Associate Deputy Attorney General Paul Perkins as acting Register of Copyrights and Director of the U.S. Copyright Office.

Perlmutter brought two counts challenging these actions. Count I alleged that the President's appointment of Blanche as acting Librarian was ultra vires, arguing that the Federal Vacancies Reform Act does not authorize presidential appointment of acting officials in the Library of Congress because it is not an "Executive agency" under the statute. Count II claimed violations of the Constitution's Appointments Clause and separation of powers doctrine, contending that only the Librarian of Congress has statutory authority under 17 U.S.C. § 701(a) to appoint and remove the Register of Copyrights, not the President or his appointees.

Perlmutter sought declaratory and injunctive relief to prevent defendants from interfering with her lawful appointment and to declare that she remains the Register of Copyrights. The case arose in the context of the Copyright Office's work on a multi-part report addressing copyright issues related to artificial intelligence, with Part 3 being released just before Perlmutter's removal.

On May 22, 2025, Perlmutter moved for a temporary restraining order. After briefing and a hearing on May 28, 2025, Judge Kelly denied the motion, finding that Perlmutter had not established irreparable harm. Following a status conference, the court established a briefing schedule for a preliminary injunction motion.

Perlmutter filed her preliminary injunction motion on June 10, 2025. After full briefing and a hearing on July 23, 2025, Judge Kelly issued a detailed memorandum opinion on July 30, 2025, denying the motion. The court concluded that Perlmutter failed to demonstrate irreparable harm, applying the Supreme Court's standard from Sampson v. Murray that preliminary injunctions in government personnel cases require a "genuinely extraordinary situation." Judge Kelly rejected Perlmutter's arguments that her temporary loss of a "statutory right to function," inability to perform statutory duties, or institutional harm to the Library of Congress and Copyright Office constituted irreparable harm, noting that recent Supreme Court and D.C. Circuit decisions had stayed similar injunctions in comparable officer-removal cases.

Perlmutter appealed the preliminary injunction denial to the D.C. Circuit on July 31, 2025, and filed an emergency motion for injunction pending appeal. On August 20, 2025, Judge Kelly denied that motion as well, reiterating that Perlmutter had not shown irreparable harm. The case remains on appeal to the D.C. Circuit under case number 25-5285, while the district court has scheduled cross-motions for summary judgment with a hearing set for November 4, 2025.

This case was filed on April 20, 2023, by parents Ashley Willey and Sean Willey against Sweetwater County School District #1's Board of Trustees and four individual defendants: Superintendent Kelly McGovern, Assistant Superintendent Nicole Bolton, Director of Student Services Kayci Arnoldi, and Principal Bryant Blake. The parents were represented by private counsel from Bailey Stock Harmon Cottam Lopez LLP and the Child & Parental Rights Campaign.

The lawsuit arose from the school district's implementation of a policy regarding transgender students that the parents alleged violated their fundamental constitutional rights. The parents' daughter, A.S., was a 16-year-old student at Black Butte High School who had a history of childhood trauma and was receiving treatment for ADHD, PTSD, and symptoms of gender dysphoria from a private counselor chosen by her parents.

During the 2021-2022 school year, A.S. told school staff she wanted to be treated as a boy, use the male name "C" and male pronouns, and requested that this information be concealed from her parents. Pursuant to district policy, school personnel agreed to this arrangement and for over six months treated A.S. as a boy at school while using her legal name and female pronouns when communicating with her parents. The parents only discovered this deception in March 2022 when Mrs. Willey happened to meet teachers at a district training who inadvertently revealed the situation.

The district had implemented what the parents termed "the Policy," consisting of two components: a "Preferred Names Policy" requiring staff to use students' preferred names and pronouns even if they differ from biological sex, and a "Parent Concealment Policy" requiring staff to conceal this information from parents unless the student consents. Mrs. Willey, who was also employed as a teacher by the district, was told she must comply with the Policy despite her religious objections and was denied accommodations for her religious beliefs.

The parents brought claims under 42 U.S.C. § 1983, alleging violations of their Fourteenth Amendment substantive due process rights to direct their children's upbringing and make mental health decisions, and Mrs. Willey's First Amendment rights to free exercise of religion and free speech. They sought declaratory and injunctive relief as well as monetary damages.

On April 21, 2023, the parents filed a motion for preliminary injunction. Judge Scott W. Skavdahl granted the motion in part on June 30, 2023, enjoining the district from precluding employees from responding to parental inquiries about students' preferred names or pronouns and from requiring employees to lie to parents about such requests, but denied the injunction as to other aspects of the policy.

The defendants filed a motion to dismiss on June 29, 2023, but the parents filed an amended complaint on July 20, 2023, rendering the motion moot. The defendants then filed a motion to dismiss the amended complaint on August 17, 2023. On December 18, 2023, Judge Skavdahl granted the motion in part and denied it in part, allowing the parents to proceed on claims for nominal and compensatory damages on their parental rights and parental free exercise claims, dismissing Mrs. Willey's free speech claim, but allowing her individual free exercise claim to proceed.

The case proceeded through discovery with a jury trial scheduled for June 2, 2025. However, on March 24, 2025, the defendants filed a motion for summary judgment. On April 28, 2025, Judge Skavdahl granted summary judgment in favor of the defendants on all remaining claims and dismissed Sean Willey from the action, leaving Ashley Willey as the sole remaining plaintiff before dismissing all her claims as well.

The plaintiffs filed a notice of appeal on May 23, 2025, appealing to the Tenth Circuit Court of Appeals under case number 25-8027. The case involved significant issues regarding the balance between parental rights, student privacy, and religious accommodation in public schools in the context of transgender student policies.

This class action lawsuit was filed on May 10, 2016, by over thirty current and former residents of the Alexander County Housing Authority (ACHA) against ACHA, Executive Director James Wilson, and Finance Director Martha Franklin. The plaintiffs were represented by private counsel from Hughes, Socol, Piers, Resnick & Dym, Ltd. and attorneys from the Sargent Shriver National Center on Poverty Law. The case was assigned to Chief Judge Michael J. Reagan with Magistrate Judge Reona J. Daly handling case management.

The plaintiffs alleged that ACHA engaged in racial and familial status discrimination at its McBride and Elmwood family housing developments in violation of the Fair Housing Act, Title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, and the Illinois Civil Rights Act of 2003. According to the complaint, approximately 97% of residents in McBride and Elmwood were African-American, while white households predominated in other ACHA developments like Connell Smith. The plaintiffs claimed this segregation was intentional and echoed discriminatory practices from decades earlier—the U.S. Department of Justice had sued ACHA in 1974 for intentionally segregating these same housing complexes by race, resulting in a settlement agreement.

The factual basis of the case centered on ACHA's alleged failure to maintain the McBride and Elmwood developments in decent, safe, and sanitary conditions while adequately maintaining developments with more white residents. Plaintiffs described units infested with mice, roaches, and bedbugs; serious mold problems; broken plumbing, heating, and electrical systems; and security issues. Meanwhile, ACHA allegedly maintained the Connell Smith development in satisfactory condition and provided security cameras and guards. The complaint also alleged that ACHA improperly prohibited families with children from living in certain developments like Connell Smith and Shoemaker, which did not qualify as senior housing under federal law.

The plaintiffs sought to certify multiple subclasses: a race discrimination subclass for African-American residents of McBride and Elmwood; a familial status discrimination subclass for residents with minor children; and a residential lease breach subclass. They requested declaratory and injunctive relief to stop the discriminatory practices, along with compensatory and punitive damages, and attorney's fees.

The case proceeded through discovery with various disputes over document production, including executive session minutes and email searches. HUD's 2014 finding that ACHA had violated Title VI through intentional racial segregation was referenced as supporting evidence. The case underwent several amendments to the complaint, adding additional plaintiffs and refining the legal claims.

Settlement discussions began in 2016 and continued through 2017. During the settlement process, some plaintiffs' attorneys moved to withdraw from representing certain clients who had become unresponsive. On July 27, 2017, the represented plaintiffs filed a stipulation of dismissal, agreeing to dismiss their claims with prejudice and without costs, with each party bearing its own attorney's fees. Three plaintiffs (Latonya Lee, Denieshia Childress, and Coretta Cornelius) had lost counsel and were proceeding pro se, but they failed to respond to court orders or participate in proceedings. Chief Judge Reagan dismissed their claims for failure to prosecute on August 1 and September 12, 2017. The case was closed on September 12, 2017, with all claims resolved through the settlement and dismissals for failure to prosecute.

The United States filed this civil rights enforcement action against the South Carolina Department of Juvenile Justice on April 14, 2022, under the pattern or practice provision of the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act, 34 U.S.C. § 12601. The case was assigned to Judge Mary Geiger Lewis in the U.S. District Court for the District of South Carolina. The Department of Justice's Civil Rights Division and the U.S. Attorney's Office for the District of South Carolina represented the United States.

The lawsuit arose from a DOJ investigation that began in 2017 examining conditions at the Broad River Road Complex (BRRC), South Carolina's long-term juvenile commitment facility. The facility houses youth aged 17 and younger who have been adjudicated delinquent, with an average daily population of over 100 youth and average stays of six to seven months. The investigation involved multiple site visits, staff and youth interviews, document review, and video analysis.

DOJ issued two findings reports documenting constitutional violations. The February 5, 2020 report concluded that the Department of Juvenile Justice failed to keep youth reasonably safe from youth-on-youth violence and subjected youth to prolonged, punitive isolation in violation of the Fourteenth Amendment Due Process Clause. The April 14, 2022 report found that staff used excessive force against youth. Specifically, DOJ found that between July 2018 and May 2019, there were 134 fights and 71 assaults resulting in 99 injuries to youth, with violence occurring on average two out of every three days. Staff engaged in dangerous tactics including choking, punching, kicking, and twisting youth's arms, often in response to verbal non-compliance rather than physical threats. Youth were placed in isolation for minor infractions like profanity or disrespect, sometimes for weeks or months in small, dark cells for 23 hours daily without meaningful education or programming. These conditions led to self-harm attempts and deteriorating mental health among youth.

The case was resolved through a comprehensive settlement agreement signed by the parties on April 13, 2022, the day before the complaint was filed. The agreement addresses staffing levels, physical plant security, use of force policies, isolation practices, staff training, investigation procedures, and quality assurance systems. Key provisions include conducting a staffing study, eliminating blind spots through improved surveillance, implementing positive behavior management programs, restricting use of force to situations involving immediate danger, limiting isolation to four hours except with supervisory approval, providing meaningful education during any isolation, and establishing a multidisciplinary team to review isolation placements.

The settlement includes extensive monitoring through a Subject Matter Expert to be jointly selected by the parties, with a budget not exceeding $225,000 in the first year. The expert will conduct semi-annual compliance assessments and provide technical assistance. DJJ appointed Wendy Leach as Director of Settlement Compliance to coordinate implementation. The agreement establishes a five-year term, subject to early termination if substantial compliance is achieved and maintained for one year.

On April 14, 2022, the parties filed a joint motion for conditional dismissal, which Judge Lewis granted on April 20, 2022. The court dismissed the case without prejudice while retaining jurisdiction to resolve any disputes over compliance with the settlement agreement. The judgment was entered the same day, with the case remaining subject to potential reinstatement if material breach occurs.

On May 21, 2025, a federal grand jury in the Middle District of Tennessee indicted Kilmar Armando Abrego Garcia on two counts related to human smuggling: conspiracy to unlawfully transport illegal aliens for financial gain and illegal transportation of illegal aliens for financial gain, both in violation of 8 U.S.C. § 1324. The charges stem from a November 30, 2022 traffic stop by Tennessee Highway Patrol, during which Abrego was allegedly driving a vehicle containing nine individuals who were being transported illegally for financial compensation.

The case is presided over by District Judge Waverly D. Crenshaw, Jr., with Magistrate Judge Barbara D. Holmes handling pretrial matters. Abrego is represented by Federal Public Defender attorneys and later private counsel, including pro hac vice attorneys Sean Hecker, Jenna Dabbs, and David Patton.

The government's evidence includes testimony from cooperating witnesses who claim Abrego participated in a broader human smuggling conspiracy operated by a business called "Trans Express," phone records showing communications with the conspiracy's leader during the traffic stop, and a roster allegedly showing that one of the transported individuals was a minor. The government argued that Abrego transported approximately 120 undocumented individuals and was paid $1,000-$1,500 per trip.

A significant backdrop to this prosecution is Abrego's immigration history. He had been living in the United States for over a decade with his family and had an immigration court order granting withholding of removal to El Salvador. However, he was removed to El Salvador in March 2025. A federal court in Maryland ordered his return, leading to the Supreme Court case Noem v. Abrego Garcia, 145 S. Ct. 1017 (2025), which affirmed that the government must facilitate his return from El Salvador. He was arrested upon his return to the United States on June 6, 2025.

The government filed a motion for pretrial detention, arguing that the case involved minor victims under 18 U.S.C. § 3142(f)(1)(E), that Abrego posed a serious risk of flight, and that he posed a danger to the community. On June 22, 2025, Magistrate Judge Holmes denied the detention motion in a detailed 51-page memorandum opinion, finding that the government failed to establish grounds for a detention hearing and that conditions of release could reasonably assure Abrego's appearance and community safety.

The government appealed the release decision to the district court. Following a July 16, 2025 evidentiary hearing, District Judge Crenshaw issued a July 23, 2025 memorandum opinion denying the government's motion for revocation of the release order. The specific federal programs at issue included the Federal Employees Health Benefits Program (FEHB), the Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA), Social Security survivor benefits, federal income tax filing status, and ERISA-governed pension benefits. Each plaintiff couple demonstrated concrete financial and personal harms from being treated as unmarried for federal purposes despite their valid state marriages.

After the Department of Justice announced in February 2011 that it would no longer defend DOMA's constitutionality, the Bipartisan Legal Advisory Group of the U.S. House of Representatives successfully intervened in May 2011 to defend the statute. Judge Vanessa L. Bryant presided over the case.

Following discovery, the plaintiffs moved for summary judgment in July 2011, while BLAG moved to dismiss. The court denied BLAG's motion to stay proceedings in July 2012. On July 31, 2012, Judge Bryant issued a comprehensive 104-page decision granting the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment and denying BLAG's motion to dismiss.

The district court's decision included extensive analysis of whether sexual orientation classifications should receive heightened scrutiny under equal protection doctrine, examining factors such as history of discrimination, immutability, and political powerlessness. However, the court ultimately found it unnecessary to definitively resolve the standard of review because DOMA failed even rational basis review.

The court systematically rejected each rationale offered by Congress and BLAG for DOMA, including defending traditional marriage, promoting responsible procreation, preserving government resources, and maintaining administrative consistency. The court concluded that DOMA violated the Fifth Amendment's guarantee of equal protection and declared Section 3 unconstitutional as applied to the plaintiffs.

Both the federal defendants and BLAG appealed to the Second Circuit Court of Appeals on August 17, 2012, and multiple parties filed petitions for certiorari before judgment with the Supreme Court. The case was part of a broader wave of constitutional challenges to DOMA that ultimately led to the Supreme Court's decision in United States v. Windsor in 2013.
results.PC-AL-0034:
The United States filed this lawsuit on May 28, 2015, against the State of Alabama and Alabama Department of Corrections under the Civil Rights of Institutionalized Persons Act, seeking to stop constitutional violations at the Julia Tutwiler Prison for Women. The case arose from a Department of Justice investigation that began in February 2013 and concluded in January 2014 with findings that Alabama violated the Eighth Amendment by failing to protect women prisoners from sexual abuse and harassment by correctional staff.

The DOJ investigation revealed systemic and pervasive sexual abuse spanning nearly two decades at Tutwiler. Investigators found that staff members raped, sodomized, fondled, and sexually harassed women prisoners, with at least 36 of the facility's 99 employees identified as having engaged in sexual conduct with inmates. The facility operated with what the DOJ characterized as a "toxic, sexualized environment" where women prisoners were forced to submit to unlawful sexual advances to obtain basic necessities or avoid punishment. Prison officials failed to adequately investigate allegations, discouraged reporting through retaliation, and demonstrated deliberate indifference to known risks. The investigation also identified numerous systemic deficiencies including dangerously low staffing levels, architectural problems that compromised privacy, lack of gender-responsive policies, and an inadequate classification system.

On the same day the complaint was filed, the parties jointly moved for court approval of a comprehensive settlement agreement they had negotiated. Judge Myron H. Thompson approved the settlement on June 18, 2015, entering it as a consent decree while conditionally dismissing the complaint without prejudice and retaining jurisdiction for enforcement purposes.

The settlement agreement established extensive reform requirements across multiple areas including mandatory zero-tolerance policies for sexual abuse and harassment, comprehensive staff training programs, installation of a state-of-the-art camera surveillance system, adequate staffing requirements, inmate education programs, development of gender-responsive classification and programming systems, enhanced privacy protections, multiple reporting mechanisms for allegations, detailed investigation procedures, staff disciplinary protocols, and ongoing quality improvement and data collection systems.

The agreement provided for independent monitoring of compliance, with court-appointed monitor Jennie Lancaster initially overseeing implementation, later replaced by Kathleen Dennehy in August 2016. The monitors filed detailed compliance reports every six months documenting steady progress, from 12 provisions in substantial compliance in the first report to 41 provisions in substantial compliance by the eighth report in August 2019. Key areas of ongoing challenge included chronic staffing shortages and recruitment difficulties, particularly for female correctional officers.

The case demonstrates the federal government's use of CRIPA to address systemic constitutional violations in state correctional facilities, resulting in comprehensive court-supervised reform through a detailed consent decree with ongoing monitoring and reporting requirements lasting several years.
results.ED-MI-0001:
On November 8, 2006, the day after Michigan voters approved Proposal 2 by a 58-42% margin, the Coalition to Defend Affirmative Action, Integration and Immigrant Rights and Fight for Equality by Any Means Necessary (BAMN) and other organizations and individuals filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan challenging the constitutional amendment. Proposal 2, which became Article I, Section 26 of the Michigan Constitution, prohibited the state's public universities and other governmental entities from granting "preferential treatment" based on race, sex, color, ethnicity, or national origin in public education, employment, and contracting. The plaintiffs named as defendants Governor Jennifer Granholm, the governing boards of the University of Michigan, Michigan State University, and Wayne State University, along with university presidents.

A separate but similar lawsuit was filed on December 19, 2006, by the Cantrell Plaintiffs, consisting of University of Michigan faculty members, students, and prospective students. District Judge David M. Lawson consolidated the cases on January 5, 2007. Michigan Attorney General Michael Cox intervened as a defendant, while Eric Russell, a law school applicant, and several other entities sought to intervene supporting Proposal 2.

The plaintiffs' legal challenge rested primarily on two constitutional theories. First, they argued that Proposal 2 violated the Equal Protection Clause under the "political process" doctrine established in Hunter v. Erickson and Washington v. Seattle School District No. 1, claiming the amendment impermissibly restructured Michigan's political process by requiring constitutional amendment—rather than normal legislative or administrative processes—to restore race-conscious admissions policies. Second, they contended Proposal 2 constituted intentional discrimination against racial minorities. The Coalition Plaintiffs also raised claims under the First Amendment and federal civil rights statutes including Title VI, Title VII, and Title IX.

Both plaintiff groups sought class certification and filed motions for summary judgment. The defendants responded with their own summary judgment motions. Procedural complications arose when university defendants initially sought to be dismissed as unnecessary parties, and when Russell's status as an intervenor was challenged after his law school application was denied.

On December 19, 2006, the court issued a temporary injunction postponing Proposal 2's application to university admissions until July 1, 2007, based on a stipulation among the parties. However, the Sixth Circuit granted a stay of this injunction on December 29, 2006, allowing Proposal 2 to take immediate effect. The circuit court noted there was an "absence of any likelihood of prevailing in invalidating [Proposal 2] on federal grounds" and suggested Proposal 2 "would seem to be an equal-protection virtue, not an equal-protection vice."

On March 18, 2008, District Judge Lawson granted summary judgment for the Attorney General and dismissed all claims, finding that Proposal 2 did not violate the Equal Protection Clause. The court distinguished the case from Hunter and Seattle, reasoning that those precedents applied only when laws denied minorities "equal protection" rather than merely precluding "preferential treatment." The court also dismissed Russell as an intervenor, finding he no longer had a distinct interest after his law school application was denied.

The plaintiffs appealed, and a Sixth Circuit panel reversed in a 2-1 decision in 2011, concluding that Proposal 2 violated the Hunter/Seattle doctrine by impermissibly restructuring the political process along racial lines. The panel majority found that race-conscious admissions policies "inure primarily to the benefit of the minority" and that Proposal 2 placed special burdens on racial minorities by moving decision-making authority over such policies from university governing boards to the state constitutional level.

The Sixth Circuit sitting en banc affirmed the panel decision in November 2012 by an 8-7 vote. The majority opinion, written by Judge Cole, applied the Hunter/Seattle two-prong test: finding that Proposal 2 had a "racial focus" because it targeted policies primarily benefiting minorities, and that it reordered the political process by requiring constitutional amendment to restore race-conscious policies while leaving other admissions criteria subject to normal administrative processes.

The case reached the Supreme Court, which heard oral arguments on October 15, 2013. On April 22, 2014, the Court reversed the Sixth Circuit in a 6-2 decision (with Justice Kagan recused), upholding Proposal 2's constitutionality. Justice Kennedy's plurality opinion, joined by Chief Justice Roberts and Justice Alito, distinguished Hunter and Seattle as cases involving "demonstrated injuries on the basis of race that, by reasons of state encouragement or participation, became more aggravated." The plurality found that unlike those precedents, Proposal 2 did not inflict specific racial injuries but rather represented a democratic choice about whether to continue race-based preferences. Justice Scalia, joined by Justice Thomas, concurred in the judgment but argued for overruling the Hunter/Seattle doctrine entirely. Justice Breyer also concurred separately. Justice Sotomayor, joined by Justice Ginsburg, dissented, arguing that the majority failed to understand the continuing effects of racial inequality.

The Supreme Court's decision definitively resolved the eight-year litigation, allowing Michigan's constitutional prohibition on affirmative action to stand and affecting similar laws in other states. The case represented a significant constitutional ruling on the intersection of democratic processes, equal protection, and affirmative action policies in public higher education.
results.DR-CA-0033:
Maurizio Antoninetti, a paraplegic who uses a wheelchair for mobility, filed this Americans with Disabilities Act lawsuit on August 22, 2005, against Chipotle Mexican Grill, Inc., challenging the accessibility of two Chipotle restaurants in San Diego and Encinitas, California. The case was initially assigned to Judge Napoleon A. Jones Jr. and later transferred to Judge Barry Ted Moskowitz. Antoninetti was represented by private counsel Amy B. Vandeveld, while Chipotle was represented by attorneys from several firms including Greenberg Traurig.

The central issue involved Chipotle's restaurant design, where 44-inch high walls separated customers from food preparation counters containing displayed food ingredients. Standing customers could see over these walls to view food preparation and select ingredients as part of the "Chipotle experience," but wheelchair users, with average eye levels between 43-51 inches, could not see over the walls. Antoninetti argued this violated the ADA by denying wheelchair users equal access to the visual and interactive elements of ordering food.

Chipotle defended by pointing to its accommodation policies. Initially, it had an unwritten policy allowing employees to show food samples to wheelchair users in spoons, tongs, or plastic cups, or to prepare food at the lower 34-inch transaction station. In February 2007, during the litigation, Chipotle implemented a written "Customers With Disabilities Policy" formalizing these accommodations and requiring managers to proactively offer assistance to customers with disabilities.

The case proceeded through cross-motions for summary judgment filed in April 2007. On June 14, 2007, the district court granted partial summary judgment to both parties, finding that Chipotle's food preparation counters were governed by ADA Accessibility Guidelines Section 7.2(2) rather than the sight-line requirements of Section 4.33.3 that Antoninetti had argued applied. The court ruled that a genuine factual dispute existed regarding whether Chipotle's accommodation policies constituted "equivalent facilitation" under the ADA.

Following a four-day bench trial in November-December 2007, Judge Jones concluded that Chipotle's prior unwritten policy violated the ADA but that its current written policy provided equivalent facilitation and complied with the ADA. The court denied Antoninetti's request for injunctive relief to lower the restaurant walls and awarded him $5,000 in statutory damages under the California Disabled Persons Act for five "bona fide" customer visits made before the written policy was implemented. The court denied damages for three additional "litigation-related" visits.

Antoninetti appealed to the Ninth Circuit, which issued its decision in Antoninetti v. Chipotle Mexican Grill, Inc., 643 F.3d 1165 (9th Cir. 2010). The Ninth Circuit reversed the district court's finding that Chipotle's written policy complied with the ADA, holding that both the written and unwritten policies violated federal disability law. The appellate court found that Chipotle's accommodation methods did not provide substantially equivalent access to the food preparation areas and remanded for entry of judgment that Chipotle violated the ADA and for determination of appropriate injunctive relief.

However, the injunctive relief issue became moot when Antoninetti died on May 9, 2011. His widow, Livia Antoninetti, was substituted as plaintiff. On remand, the district court entered judgment against Chipotle for ADA violations but found that injunctive relief was no longer appropriate due to Antoninetti's death, as his estate lacked standing to pursue an injunction.

The case also involved extensive litigation over attorney's fees. The district court initially awarded Antoninetti's counsel $136,537.83 in fees, but after the Ninth Circuit's reversal on the merits, the fee award was reconsidered and ultimately increased to $545,079.05 for the district court proceedings, with additional fees awarded for the appellate work.

A related class action case (06cv2671) was filed and consolidated with the individual case for discovery purposes, though the cases proceeded separately for most purposes. The litigation established important precedent regarding ADA compliance in restaurant design and the adequacy of service-based accommodations versus architectural accessibility in newly constructed facilities.
results.CJ-FL-0009:
This consolidated civil rights litigation was filed beginning June 28, 2019, challenging Florida's implementation of Amendment 4, a constitutional amendment passed by Florida voters in November 2018 that restored voting rights to most people with felony convictions upon "completion of all terms of sentence including parole or probation." The plaintiffs include 17 individuals with felony convictions who cannot afford to pay their outstanding legal financial obligations (LFOs), as well as three civil rights organizations: the Florida State Conference of the NAACP, the Orange County Branch of the NAACP, and the League of Women Voters of Florida. The defendants are Florida state officials including the Governor, the Secretary of State, and various county Supervisors of Elections, all sued in their official capacities.

The legal dispute centers on Florida's Senate Bill 7066, enacted in 2019, which interpreted Amendment 4's requirement of completing "all terms of sentence" to include payment of fines, fees, costs, and restitution imposed as part of criminal sentences. The plaintiffs brought claims under 42 U.S.C. § 1983, alleging this requirement violates the Fourteenth Amendment's Equal Protection and Due Process Clauses by discriminating based on wealth, violates the Twenty-Fourth Amendment by functioning as a poll tax, and violates the First Amendment by burdening political speech and association. They sought declaratory and injunctive relief. The plaintiffs are represented by a coalition of civil rights organizations including the ACLU, NAACP Legal Defense Fund, Campaign Legal Center, and Brennan Center for Justice.

The case was initially assigned to Chief Judge Mark E. Walker but was reassigned to Judge Robert L. Hinkle. Five separate cases filed between June and July 2019 were consolidated for case management purposes under lead case number 4:19-cv-00300. After an evidentiary hearing, Judge Hinkle granted a preliminary injunction in October 2019, ruling that Florida cannot prevent people genuinely unable to pay their LFOs from registering and voting. The court certified both a class of all persons denied voting rights due to unpaid LFOs and a subclass of those genuinely unable to pay.

Following an 8-day trial in 2020, Judge Hinkle issued a permanent injunction and 125-page opinion, finding that conditioning voting rights on payment of amounts people cannot afford violates the Equal Protection Clause, and that requiring payment of fees and costs (as opposed to fines and restitution) violates the Twenty-Fourth Amendment as an unconstitutional tax on voting.

The case was appealed to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit, which initially affirmed the preliminary injunction in a panel decision (Jones v. Governor of Florida, 950 F.3d 795). However, the Eleventh Circuit then granted en banc review and in September 2020 reversed the district court's decision by a 6-4 vote. The en banc court held that rational basis review, not heightened scrutiny, applied to Florida's reenfranchisement scheme, and that the requirement to complete all terms of sentence, including financial obligations, was rationally related to legitimate state interests in ensuring full rehabilitation and completion of punishment. The court also ruled that fees and costs imposed as part of criminal sentences are penalties, not taxes, and therefore do not violate the Twenty-Fourth Amendment.

The litigation involved complex constitutional questions about the scope of voting rights for people with felony convictions, the relationship between wealth and access to the franchise, and the interpretation of constitutional amendments addressing poll taxes. The case significantly impacted voting rights in Florida, where an estimated 1.4 million people with felony convictions were potentially affected by Amendment 4's passage.
results.CW-CA-0005:
Katie A. v. Bonta was a federal class action lawsuit filed on July 18, 2002, challenging California's failure to provide adequate mental health services to foster children. The case was brought by five foster children using pseudonyms—Katie A., Mary B., Janet C., Henry D., and Gary E.—against state officials including the Directors of the California Department of Health Services and Department of Social Services, as well as Los Angeles County and its Department of Children and Family Services. The plaintiffs were represented by multiple public interest organizations including the ACLU of Southern California, Western Center on Law & Poverty, and the National Center for Youth Law.

The lawsuit alleged violations of the Early and Periodic Screening, Diagnostic and Treatment (EPSDT) provisions of the Medicaid Act, the Fourteenth Amendment's Due Process Clause, the Americans with Disabilities Act, and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act. Plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief to require defendants to provide necessary mental health services in community-based, home-like settings rather than inappropriate institutional placements.

The case was initially assigned to Judge Ronald Lew but transferred to Judge A. Howard Matz in August 2002, and later to Judge John A. Kronstadt. On June 18, 2003, the court certified a statewide class of children in California who are in foster care or at imminent risk of foster care placement, have documented mental illness or conditions, and need individualized mental health services in home or home-like settings to treat their conditions. However, plaintiff Gary E. was excluded as a class representative due to his relocation to Idaho.

The case involved extensive settlement negotiations. Plaintiffs first reached a settlement with the Los Angeles County defendants, which was approved by the court on July 16, 2003, after a fairness hearing. This settlement established an advisory panel to monitor implementation and required the county to provide wraparound services and other community-based mental health services to foster children.

Regarding the state defendants, plaintiffs filed a motion for preliminary injunction in September 2005, which Judge Matz granted on March 14, 2006. The court ordered the state to provide wraparound services and therapeutic foster care to eligible foster children within 120 days. However, the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals reversed and remanded this decision in March 2007, finding that the district court had applied an erroneous legal standard in concluding that the EPSDT provisions required the state to provide these services in specific bundled forms rather than just the individual component services.

Following the remand, the parties engaged in renewed litigation and settlement negotiations. The court eventually granted another preliminary injunction in September 2008. After extensive negotiations involving a special master and stakeholder workgroup, the parties reached a comprehensive settlement agreement that was approved by the court on December 1, 2011.

The final settlement established four key objectives: facilitating coordinated, comprehensive, community-based mental health services; supporting development of service structures and fiscal systems that support core practices; providing effective oversight and training; and ensuring that subclass members with intensive needs receive medically necessary mental health services in appropriate settings. The settlement required the state defendants to develop documentation manuals for Intensive Care Coordination (ICC) and Intensive Home Based Services (IHBS), submit amendments to California's Medicaid State Plan, establish shared management structures between state departments, and implement various training and quality assurance measures.

The factual basis for the case centered on California's foster care system, which served over 90,000 children, with most receiving health care through Medi-Cal (California's Medicaid program). The plaintiffs alleged that thousands of foster children with behavioral, emotional, and psychiatric impairments were not receiving necessary community-based mental health services such as wraparound services and therapeutic foster care. Instead, these children were often placed in inappropriate group homes or institutional settings, leading to multiple placement disruptions and deteriorating conditions. The named plaintiffs had experienced numerous placements—Katie A. had 37 placements in ten years, Mary B. had 28 placements in three years, and Janet C. had 25 placements in less than two and a half years—demonstrating the system's failure to provide stable, appropriate care.

The case remained under court supervision for implementation of the settlement terms, with ongoing monitoring through advisory panels and special masters to ensure compliance with the agreement's requirements for systemic reform of mental health services for foster children in California.
results.PC-VA-0022:
Eric J. DePaola filed this federal civil rights lawsuit under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 on December 19, 2014, in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Virginia, challenging his prolonged solitary confinement at Red Onion State Prison. DePaola was sentenced to 38 years in prison at age 16 in 2004 for crimes including malicious wounding, use of a firearm, burglary, and abduction. After stabbing a prison guard in 2009, he was placed in administrative segregation (solitary confinement) where he has remained for approximately eight years.

The case was originally filed by three plaintiffs but was severed into separate actions on April 8, 2015, with DePaola proceeding pro se. He filed an amended complaint on May 18, 2016, after the court denied defendants' motion to dismiss. DePaola's claims center on Virginia Department of Corrections Operating Procedure 830.A, which became effective February 18, 2013, and classifies segregated prisoners into two pathways: Intensive Management (IM) and Special Management (SM).

DePaola alleges that prisoners classified as IM, like himself, are permanently barred from returning to the general population and cannot participate in the Step-Down Program available to SM prisoners. He describes harsh conditions including 24-hour cell confinement in an 8x10-foot cell, constant bright lighting, minimal human contact, cavity searches before leaving his cell, and exercise in what he characterizes as a "dog-style cage." These conditions have allegedly caused him mental illness, physical deterioration, and other health problems.

His legal claims include violations of the Eighth Amendment's prohibition on cruel and unusual punishment and the Fourteenth Amendment's procedural due process guarantees. DePaola argues that his permanent solitary confinement serves no valid penological purpose and that he lacks meaningful review opportunities to progress out of segregation.

The court initially denied DePaola's motions for class certification and appointed counsel. Defendants filed a motion for summary judgment on July 28, 2016, which Judge James P. Jones granted on September 28, 2016, dismissing all claims. The court found that DePaola's conditions, while restrictive, did not violate the Constitution and that the periodic Institutional Classification Authority reviews provided sufficient process.

DePaola appealed to the Fourth Circuit Court of Appeals on October 6, 2016 (Case No. 16-7358), arguing that the district court erred in granting summary judgment without allowing discovery and that genuine disputes of material fact existed on both his procedural due process and Eighth Amendment claims. The appeal was ultimately unsuccessful, with the Fourth Circuit issuing an unpublished memorandum opinion on November 22, 2017, affirming the district court's judgment.
results.CJ-MD-0001:
Vernon Evans, Jr. filed this § 1983 civil rights action on January 19, 2006, in federal district court, challenging Maryland's lethal injection protocol under which he was scheduled to be executed during the week of February 6, 2006. Evans was represented by private counsel from Wilmer Cutler Pickering Hale and Dorr LLP, while the state defendants were represented by the Maryland Attorney General's office. Chief Judge Benson Everett Legg presided over the case.

Evans had been sentenced to death in 1984 for two contract murders and was housed at the Maryland Correctional Adjustment Center. His federal lawsuit was filed just weeks before his scheduled execution date, after a Baltimore County judge signed a warrant of execution on January 9, 2006. Evans did not challenge the fact of his death sentence or the constitutionality of lethal injection generally, but rather contested the specific practices and procedures used by the Maryland Department of Correction.

The case centered on Maryland's three-drug lethal injection protocol using sodium pentothal (an anesthetic), pancuronium bromide (a paralytic agent), and potassium chloride (which stops the heart). Evans alleged that these procedures violated the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments by creating an unnecessary risk that he would experience excruciating pain during execution. His primary concerns included inadequate medical supervision, improperly trained personnel, his compromised veins due to prior intravenous drug use, and the risk that he would not be adequately anesthetized when the painful second and third drugs were administered.

Expert testimony was provided by Dr. Mark Heath, a board-certified anesthesiologist, who testified about the medical risks of the protocol. Dr. Thomas Scalea, a trauma surgeon from the University of Maryland Shock Trauma Center, examined Evans and concluded that his veins were severely compromised and might not be suitable for peripheral IV access, potentially requiring more invasive procedures like central line placement or surgical cut-down.

Evans sought both a temporary restraining order and preliminary injunction to halt his execution. After hearings on January 24, 27, and February 1, 2006, Judge Legg denied both motions on February 1, 2006, finding that Evans had not met the requirements for injunctive relief under the Blackwelder standard. Evans immediately appealed to the Fourth Circuit Court of Appeals and sought a stay pending appeal, which was also denied.

Parallel to the federal case, Evans and organizational plaintiffs including the NAACP, ACLU of Maryland, and Maryland Citizens Against State Executions filed suit in Baltimore City Circuit Court challenging the execution protocol on state law grounds, arguing that it violated Maryland's lethal injection statute and was improperly adopted without following the Administrative Procedure Act.

The Maryland Court of Appeals ultimately consolidated four related appeals (Nos. 107, 122, 123, 124) involving various challenges to Evans's death sentence. In its December 19, 2006 decision, the court rejected Evans's constitutional claims but found merit in his Administrative Procedure Act challenge. The court ruled that portions of the execution protocol directing the manner of administering lethal injection were effectively regulations that had been adopted without compliance with the Administrative Procedure Act and were therefore invalid until either properly adopted as regulations or exempted by the legislature.

This ruling effectively enjoined Maryland from using its current lethal injection protocol and prevented Evans's execution from proceeding. The federal district court case remained stayed pending resolution of these state law issues. The case illustrates the complex interplay between federal constitutional challenges and state administrative law requirements in death penalty litigation, with the successful state law challenge ultimately providing the relief that the federal constitutional claims could not secure.
results.CW-DC-0001:
LaShawn A. v. Bowser is a class action filed on June 20, 1989, on behalf of children in the District of Columbia's foster care system and children who have been reported as abused or neglected but remain in private custody. The plaintiffs, represented by next friends and attorneys from the ACLU's Children's Rights Project, sued the Mayor of the District of Columbia and other DC officials responsible for the child welfare system under 42 U.S.C. § 1983, alleging violations of federal statutes, DC statutes, and the Fifth Amendment.

After a two-week bench trial in 1991, Judge Thomas F. Hogan issued a comprehensive 102-page opinion finding defendants liable for systemic failures in DC's child welfare system. The court found that the District had failed to comply with the Adoption Assistance and Child Welfare Act of 1980, the Child Abuse Prevention and Treatment Act, DC's Prevention of Child Abuse and Neglect Act of 1977, and the Youth Residential Facilities Licensure Act. For children in foster care, the court also found Fifth Amendment due process violations. The evidence revealed severe deficiencies including excessive caseloads, untimely investigations, inappropriate placements, lack of case planning, and children remaining in foster care for an average of nearly five years.

The parties negotiated a comprehensive 84-page Remedial Order that the court entered on August 27, 1991, establishing detailed requirements for reforming the child welfare system. The District appealed the liability finding, and the D.C. Circuit Court of Appeals affirmed in 1993 but directed the district court to base its judgment on DC law rather than federal law. This led to a Modified Final Order in January 1994 that was substantially similar to the original order.

When the District failed to comply with the remedial requirements, the court appointed limited receivers in November 1994 and then a general receiver in August 1995. The receivership lasted until 2001, during which significant improvements were made to the system. After the receivership ended, the court continued monitoring compliance through a series of implementation plans, including major plans adopted in 2003, 2007, and 2010.

Throughout the case, the Center for the Study of Social Policy has served as court-appointed monitor, regularly reporting on the District's progress in meeting specific performance standards related to child safety, permanency, and well-being. The case has involved extensive requirements covering investigation of abuse and neglect reports, placement of children in appropriate foster homes, case planning, adoption services, worker training and caseloads, and system infrastructure.

Over more than three decades of litigation, the District has gradually achieved compliance with most court-ordered requirements. As of 2019, the parties agreed to an Exit and Sustainability Plan that removed from court monitoring 56 standards the District had achieved and maintained, while continuing oversight of remaining areas needing improvement. The case represents one of the most comprehensive and long-running institutional reform efforts in child welfare, transforming a system that the court initially found "in an ongoing state of crisis" into one that meets most professional standards for child protection and foster care services.
